title: Will California hold a recall election for Governor Gavin Newsom before 1 January 2022?
possible_answers: Yes, and Newsom will be recalled
Yes, but Newsom will not be recalled
correct_answer: Yes, but Newsom will not be recalled
preds: You have fantastic conditions for what should be a likely recall but because the only opponents are meme candidates it simply isn't going to happen. It's pretty amazing to go through all this effort and not even have someone lined up with a real chance of winning.  The complete collapse of the Californian Republican Party, who brought us Gov. Arnold and Reagan, is also impressive.
I haven't seen a single poll break against Newsom in the past 3 weeks.
Slipping in my old age--I've started to develop some mild level of confidence in a smallish improvement in the good sense of California voters.   Probably a mistake.
Primarily lower due to base rate and my own ignorance on the variables.
Yes and yes, down 5%. Sometimes a wish (or vision) sounds more plausible than it actually is. Comparison class is Tinkerbell, but in that case she came back to life.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/california-recall-polls now at +6.4 points for "keep" (Newsom not recalled).
Even Trafalgar group – their polls are usually leaning a few points to Republican compared to the average - has +7 for “keep” in a recent poll.
I guess Democratic voters in CA are getting mobilized against a Pro-Trump-governor. This time, it seems different than 2003 when Schwarzenegger (R) beat Davis (D) who was a lot less popular than Newsom.
Seeing @CJH mention 538 numbers and it's worth noting hypermind just shifted to 79-87 for Not recalled.
California recall elections are messy and historically the incumbent loses

538 average had a small jump to "not reccalled"
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/california-recall-polls/

I think that this instance is merely identity theft (the criminal was grabbing ALL mail, and happened to grab 300 recall ballots in the process), but it indicates that there are few controls to prevent fraud in the recall. I expect that any election fraud or manipulation would break in Newsom's favor.
https://www.newsweek.com/california-police-find-300-recall-election-ballots-suspect-vehicle-gavin-newsom-1622339

With 20 days to go, the knock-out blow that I was expecting to hit Newsom (whether power outages, wildfires in populated areas, smoke-affected cities, drought, etc.) has not occurred and I think it is unlikely in the remaining amount of time. Furthermore, the entire Democratic party (Warren, Biden, Kamala) is rallying to Newsom's side, and literally EVERY ad served on Youtube in San Francisco is a get-out-the-vote ad against the leading opposition candidate. If a Democratic candidate was in the lead as the replacement, I think the odds would be stacked in their favor. With a Republican in the lead, I think Newsom is unlikely to be replaced.

(no change) The legal wranglings are a wild card. Almost all agree that the CA recall process is less than perfect and serious legal minds might also agree. If nothing else, the clock might run down regarding this question. It is interesting to see so little related to what the costs are. GN is far from perfect, but seriously?
One point adjustment.  Polls still seem break-even, so 50-50 might be best choice.  But polls so wrong in 2020 election.  Betting: about the same.

This seems to be becoming a little unpredictable.  The Republican appear to be more energized to remove Newsom than then the Democrats are interested in retaining him.  It appears that Independents are leaning towards removing him.  This could be close and will depend on who turnouts to vote.

Back down to favor bin 1 because of the close polling I see others are providing, as well as Biden's declining approval rating and inclining disapproval rating, which I assume will be relatively poorer around the recall. I also assume some people will see Biden's credibility in pushing for Newsom a crock of sh. Yes, California is more blue than ever before, but I would assume that the humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan that is largely to blame on Biden's responsibility, at least in what seems to be the common narrative being told, that this crisis will yield negative attitudes to Biden and Newsom if not already. Newsom has his own Laundry list of controversies, pun intended. I would assume a state with lots of Blue voters will have no problem (1) participating, (2) voting via mail (assumption), and (3) voting out a leader who is considered part of the elite and is endorsed by a president being accused of causing a humanitarian crisis.

Now there are already two poll aggregations after 538 joined in:
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/california-recall-polls/
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2021/governor/ca/2021-california-governor-recall-election-7360.html
If you take the average of these averages, is even more  tied right now.
FiveThirtyEight 	        No on recall +1.2
Real Clear Politics 	Yes on recall +0.5
Tough challenge for polling though.
Sometimes I forget briefly how bizarre California is.  Coming up some on the odds that the lad will be given the boot in favour of some thoroughgoing nutcase.

I know polls and odds show a little in favor of not recall.  But, previous recall was success.  And, Larry Elder is such a positive, articulate, knowledgeable and charismatic fellow that the more Independent, non-affiliated and moderate Democrats Californians hear him the more there will be movement toward recalling.

Putting all my chips on "will not be recalled" and holding to the end, because this seems like most mispriced question on GJOpen. The crowd says it's a 32% chance Newsom will be replaced. The frontrunner if yes wins is a climate change denier AM radio host who wants to lower minimum wage to $0 -- this in the deeply environmentalist, deeply blue state of California, where Biden just won by 29 points and where Newsom himself won by 24 points in 2018. Larry Elder is even anti-vax and anti-mask in a state where two-thirds of Californians support mask mandates and  vaccine mandates: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/08/17/trailer-california-recall-newsom-runs-vaccines-republicans-run-newsom/  This is California, not South Dakota. What's going on here? Perhaps the crowd is putting way too much weight on early polls, but the 32% is just really so far out of reality that it feels like gaslighting to see it. While my 100% on "not be recalled" is equally absurd (since nothing is really 100%, right?), hopefully it can at least slightly improve the average crowd forecast.  The earliest ballots returned so far have been disproportionately Democratic ones: https://twitter.com/CA_120/status/1427849198716653569?s=20 While it's still extremely early in the election month, this is not exactly good news for the yes-on-recall side.

High wind forecast for the next week means that 50,000 people (~1.5% of state population) have been notified the power company is likely to pre-emptively shut off their power to avoid MORE fires breaking out.
https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-08-17/pge-california-power-shutoffs-expand-dixie-fire-grows
Air quality is affected in Sacramento, but no other big cities so far.

I think his being recalled is likely, but since there is enough evidence to support a possible stay, it seems the favor is tipping back to Newsom's favor. The crowd median is dipping, but I would hope it will not dip on the other bin.

"Newsom faces what looks like a turnout challenge: while voters would marginally prefer to keep him in office at the moment, it looks like that will heavily depend on whether Democrats in his party get more motivated about it...
In the preferences of all registered voters, "no" to the recall effort is eight points higher than "yes" to recall Newsom. But among the relatively smaller group of likely voters — which includes those who say they'll definitely vote and express the most motivation to actually do so — the contest shrinks to a four-point "no" edge for Newsom."
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/california-vaccinated-say-unvaccinated-add-risk-opinion-poll/
> ramains a tough one to predict

Making my estimate more pro-Newsom, because the most recent polling shows him in the lead 52 to 48 (although that's within the margin of error). If Newsom was certain to lose, I would've expected the anti-Newsom vote to continue to build momentum (which it hasn't since the last poll).

https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/08/12/biden-comes-to-newsoms-recall-defense-as-white-house-mulls-larger-role-1389876 “A source familiar with White House planning said both Biden and Harris intend to take an active role in the campaign’s homestretch. That could include in-person appearances and social media support” Biden and Harris won California by almost 30 points. Biden has a net approval in the state  of  22 points. I don’t know how the crowd odds aren’t in the high 90s. Newsom does not have a viable Democratic opponent. It’s not like 2003 when some voters preferred Bustamante to Davis and so voted yes for that reason. Newsom’s main opponent, Larry Elder, is a Trump supporter. Trump himself always got his lowest approval ratings in California and remains deeply unpopular there

I would say the base rate is high, but Biden just endorsed Vote NO movement. But it seems GOP members are also encouraging Vote NO, which may be seen by others as suspicious and cause them to vote against Newsom. But I'll take the two most naive views right now: (1) base rate is high, and (2) there are so many controversies attached to this man, Newsom, that his chances are not rather strong. A semi-naive view is that there are other candidates vying for his position, which is a threatening position for Newsom. How strong the others are? I don't know. If anyone asks me about base rate, I'll have a difficult time finding and articulating this. Do the research yourself.

I changed my forecast from 51% to 40% likelihood of a successful recall - I think that sending ballots to all registered voters may help Newsom as, in the end, many Democratic voters might entertain the small effort of sending off a No to the recall in order to prevent a Republican governor. 
Will see what the next polls show, there should be a couple coming in the next weeks.
https://calmatters.org/politics/2021/05/gavin-newsom-recall-money/  "Supporters of the recall have raised approximately $5.1 million and opponents have raised about $46.9 million."

California just shut down another 1% of state power generation today (generated by hydro at Oroville) because water levels are too low to operate. I think this is a strong signal that the remaining ~4% of state power being generated by hydro is at risk as well.
https://www.politico.com/states/california/whiteboard/2021/08/05/california-hits-drought-milestone-as-oroville-hydropower-stops-for-first-time-1389642

Most recent polling (SurveyUSA for San Diego Union-Tribune) shows 51% of likely voters that will support recall vs 40% supporting Newsom, which is a 10% increase in recall propensity since the poll 2 weeks ago. Recent Emerson College poll also showed 50% recall.
https://www.businessinsider.com/california-governor-gavin-newsom-recall-poll-2021-8?amp 1) Beyond the recall polling trend, a water state of emergency was declared this week for the San Joaquin watershed (Sacramento + San Francisco Bay Area). ~85% of water users (industry and farmers) are forbidden from using any. 
2) Power state of emergency was declared the week prior. 
3) The Dixie fire is now the 6th largest fire in California history and is only 36% contained. 
4) Another fire (River Fire) started yesterday. 0% contained.
5) McFarland fire has burned 33 square miles so far and is 7% contained. 
I doubt any of these disasters will be resolved favorably for Newsom before the recall vote.
https://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/fire-engulfs-northern-california-town-leveling-businesses-79282608

SurveyUSA has 51% Yes and 40% No (https://www.surveyusa.com/client/PollReport.aspx?g=36cdcb0b-7cfa-4b55-8704-d1f02a9fe6e5 ).
Beginning of May, the same pollster had 36% Yes, 47% No (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_California_gubernatorial_recall_election#Polling )
It remains still a tricky vote to predict. Pollsters (also SurveyUSA) sometimes ask / analyze only “likely voters” – however we know from research that respondents’ predictions about their participation (“I will participate in this election”) are only partially valid. Especially as this is going to  be an “All mail” vote, with all registered voters to receive ballots automatically (https://ballotpedia.org/Gavin_Newsom_recall,_Governor_of_California_(2019-2021)#Will_all_registered_voters_receive_a_ballot_by_mail_for_the_recall_election.3F ,  https://podcasts.apple.com/at/podcast/fivethirtyeight-politics/id1077418457?i=1000530808668). Finding the ballot in their mail, many Californians would perhaps participate although they hadn’t planned to. And one thing is for certain: The higher participation, the better Newsom’s chances for political survival.
Yes and yes up 8%. Not looking too rosy for team D.

31JUL21 California formally declared a State of Emergency due to Power shortages. If Newsom has rolling blackouts over the next 6 weeks I would say he'll be recalled.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-30/california-governor-orders-state-of-emergency-to-avert-blackouts

Newsom remains heavily favored for many reasons, but this latest poll of San Diego voters is very bad news for him: https://www.10news.com/news/local-news/poll-shows-surveyed-san-diego-voters-in-favor-of-recalling-newsom

There is growing evidence that this could be a tight race. [1]  A few polls have come out recently giving Newsom only a slight advantage ~3-5%. However, a lot depends on turnout which is hard to estimate for this election (off-cycle, etc). California is largely democratic, but state governors do not always align with the state's national preferences. Similarly, Republicans seem a lot more excited about the election. However, maybe these polls are enough of a shock that Democrats will go out and vote. The election is in September it seems, so still a lot of time.  [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/gavin-newsom-has-reason-to-worry/

"a new Berkeley IGS survey deploying a strict likely voter screen shows Newsom in some trouble, unless Democrats become more interested in voting during the next seven weeks. Among the voters 'most likely' to participate in the election, 47 percent favor giving the incumbent the boot while 50 percent are opposed. Among registered voters, by contrast, only 36 percent support recalling Newsom while 51 percent are opposed."
https://nymag.com/intelligencer/2021/07/gavin-newsom-needs-democrats-to-get-worried-about-the-recall.html

I learned an important piece of information that to me makes this a lock that Newsom wins. Every registered voter in California will receive a ballot in the mail: https://fox5sandiego.com/news/local-news/all-registered-voters-will-receive-mail-ballot-for-california-recall-election/  On the margin this makes a significant difference, because the only real chance he would lose is if Republicans turned out while apathetic Democrats stayed home. However, that won't be an issue. Voters will have an entire month to fill out the ballot and won't have to pay postage

Even the crowd's 95% seems a bit low at this point. California is significantly bluer today than it was in 2003, Newsom has a higher approval than Gray Davis did, there's no Democratic equivalent to Cruz Bustamante (so no Democratic pressure for yes on recall), and the polling lead for "no" has been pretty consistent.

2) CA farmers are already abandoning crops because they don't have enough water. This will exacerbate inflation, reduce state agricultural revenue, and aggravate farmers.

1) Newsom won't be listed as a 'Democrat' on the ballot due to a filing error.
2) California wildfires have already burned 3x more acreage than at this time a year ago (when the sky turned orange). 
3) Power outages are beginning (months earlier than last year), with an emergency declared 08JUL21 due to the Heat Dome.
4) 12JUL21 "Fires in Oregon knocked-out three major power transmission lines to California."

There is enough anger for an election but who would replace him?
Everything depends on turnout. And that's hard to predict. Still, it's hard to imagine a successful recall with no high-profile alternative candidate.

Recall election moved from November (a month after the historically-worst month - October - for wildfires and power outages) to 14SEP (BEFORE the worst month for wildfires and power outages). I'm therefore drastically reducing my 45% chance of Newsom recall to 15%. Polls are holding at a steady 40% of the state will vote for his recall. I think there is still a chance of a fire or power related disaster over the next 75 days though, which may move the numbers.
https://www.latimes.com/california/story/2021-07-01/california-governor-newsom-recall-election-set-for-september
Yes, yes up 1%. Former mayor of San Diego. One just has to have an alternative that is sellable, whether it is truthful or not.
Would be nice if they finally set a date for this recall election.
Yes, not up 1% to be on my preferred side of the consensus.
You don’t have creative power over something unless you can destroy it.

Elections are never 100% sure, even the president winning the electoral college isn't 100%. The crowd here says it is almost certain by a mere 3%. I think the crowd has the wrong base rate in light of the fact that the recall election is already balloted, which drops the certainty significantly. Newsom is also on the news for many controversial things. The previous successful recall didn't seem to be one of tumultuous reason, so Newson facing a successful recall is not out of reach. My forecast takes my findings and leans a bit to the crowd.

Newsom isn't in a controversial enough state to warrant a recall and it would lead to the end of many political careers if it goes through. A recall might go through (but I'd be very surprised) but it wouldn't receive enough support to go through.
Odds are slim that Newsome will not be recalled, but we still have no idea what the race is going to look like.
Newsom continues to have no significant opponents

"Ten recall efforts collected enough signatures to qualify for the ballot and of those, the elected official was recalled in six instances." Looking at the list of available candidates, is there anyone voters want more than Newsom? https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2021_California_gubernatorial_recall_election#Declared In 12 polls, 11 had Newsom holding onto his seat. One had recall at 47-42, with a MOE of 3.9%, which doesn't inspire a lot of confidence.

Gavin Newsom tweeted about a $75 billion give away over the next 6 months preceding the recall election. "$600 checks. Wiping away rental debt. Grants for small business. Universal Pre-K. Cutting the cost of college. Housing for 65,000 homeless. Historical amounts to combat wildfires." Makes me think Newsom is much less confident about his recall survival than the odds presently shown on GJOpen. Also reminds me of the budget surplus that (Democrat) Corzine burned through before the 2009 New Jersey Gubernatorial election trying to (unsuccessfully) fend off (Republican) Chris Christie.
https://twitter.com/GavinNewsom/status/1393335281877610497 On top of that, this year is shaping up to be a worse drought year than the past 2 (which were horrific... does everyone remember the photos of San Francisco with an orange sky?), and Newsom is fighting to retain his governorship with 6 months of peak wildfire season during a mega-drought to go. There will be a LOT of power outages, evacuations, and more 'Martian skies' before the recall vote.
https://www.nationalgeographic.com/environment/article/megadrought-persists-in-western-us-as-another-extremely-dry-year-develops
https://www.newyorker.com/culture/video-dept/the-day-the-san-francisco-sky-turned-orange

The ship has completely sailed on this effort in my mind. With California opening up, a huge budget surplus and no Republican candidate really doing anything this will turn out to be a wasted effort and Gavin will not be recalled.
Yes, yes down 8% on polling and surplus.

The polling continues to support the fact that Newsom will not be recalled, but the race has yet to shape up.  At the same time, the conditions in California seems to be improving on a number of fronts.
I think the slate of candidate options for a replacement is causing voters to rethink this/ The Decathlon Gold Medialist does not appear to have the umph to drag it across the finish line.

History and polls do not support high confidence. The fact that a recall was called against a Democratic leader in one of the most Democratic states is to be considered. Could increase as I learn more about Jenner and potential competition and controversies that may arise.
Recalled up 5% to be ahead of the consensus.
In Newsom vs. Caitlyn Jenner in the recall, I think Newsom has better than even odds to win.

Looking at previous US Governor Recall Elections ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recall_election#United_States Success = 67% = 2/3 = (1) 1921 North Dakota, (2) 2003 California
Failure = 33% = 1/3 = (1) 2012 Wisconsin  Looking specifically at the 2021 California Recall Election against the Democratic Governor Newsom -> Unlike the 2003 Recall Election which had a history of recent Republican office holders, Democrats are now completely dominant in California ->
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_party_strength_in_California Additionally, with the election expected to take place in November when (hopefully) the effects of Covid will have significantly reduced and the present absence of a Arnold Schwarzenegger level Republican challenger, I don't believe that the recall will be successful ->
Newson Recall Successful = 25%
Newson Recall Unsuccessful = 75%

https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2021/4/27/us-california-governor-recall-has-signatures-to-make-ballot
There will be a recall vote.  It is likely to be a ho-hum sort of affair unless the Rs come up with a serious and already well-known candidate.  Still, it's California.

Now that it appears to be all but official that there will be a recall election of Governor Newsom in California, it is time to take a closer look at this question.  On the face of the situation, it would seem that Newsom is highly unlikely to be recalled.  Current polling has only 40% of California supportive of recalling Newsom.  That is higher than the 34.3% that Trump got in the state last year, which suggests that those supporting Newsom's recall are not just hardcore Republicans.  This is important, because the last time a California Governor was recalled, Grey Davis, it was independent voters that really did him in.  However, Newsom is not Davis.  Newsom remains fairly popular among Democrats and most independents at the moment, while at the same point in the Davis recall, the Governor had an almost 2-to-1 disapproval rating.  Additionally, California has become more Democratic and liberal since the Davis recall.  Another factor in the Davis recall was the entry of Arnold Schwarzenegger as an alterative.  I have not seen any data to support this, but I have to wonder if Schwarzenegger's entry into the race contributed or at least compounded the ultimate result of the recall of Governor Davis, which was 55.4% in favor.  Would the percentage had been lower or could David have survived the recall if Schwarzenegger had not entered the race?  The reason I raise this question is the recent announcement of Caitlyn Jenner as an alternative candidate to Newsom if he is recalled.  Jenner certainly does not have name recognition nor the star power of Schwarzenegger, and her employment of Trump staffers and consultants will certainly be an issue that does not play well in California, but could it increase the likelihood that Newsom is recalled?  I believe it remains unlikely that Newsom is recalled, but I am adjusting my forecast to account for the marginal probability that it does and other possible unforeseen factors.

Yes up 3%.  Key questions: Can CJ rebrand herself as a "not crazy" maga person? Can she get $ (probably yes)? Who will vote and what will the turn out be? Will GN be forgiven his missteps?  And as we all remember, this is the way Arnold came to the governorship. Magic 8 Ball (tm) says "future cloudy, try again."

Whether Caitlyn Jenner manages to energize the Republican voters remains to be seen...I go from 99 to 97% for Newsom to remain Governor and wait for polls
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/23/us/politics/caitlyn-jenner-california-governor.html

Signatures are in hand (reportedly, https://calmatters.org/explainers/recalling-california-governor-explained/) but who will oppose him? By the time of the election, Covid19 is either handled due to vaccination and other events will be in the forefront of attention (wild fires, droughts, ++), or a mutation has showed up that locks everything down again. In the latter case, Newsom just needs to show resolve and will get enough support in a moment of crisis to get through. There's a small chance however that someone with enough name recognition will put their name on the ballot, and Ca. will get a new "Governator".

A survey conducted in March by the Public Policy Institute of California showed that 56 percent of likely voters in the state would vote not to recall Newsom, while 40 percent would vote to recall him. https://www.reviewjournal.com/sports/betting/will-california-gov-gavin-newsom-be-recalled-you-can-bet-on-it-2328504/
By the time an eventual election occurs, anger around Newsom will likely have dissipated.
So far there's no viable opponent, so I am moving these odds up
(no change) But I am trying to process the Kardasian aspect. Comparison class is Jesse Ventura. Of course would CA voters not make good choices? ;-)
Reset.  With Covid diminishing, the energy behind the recall will wither.
Newsom is popular, no Democratic opponent in sight, and also no Republican in the Schwarzenegger league
At this point, polls show he is unlikely to be removed from office.  Still a long way to go.  https://www.kcra.com/article/riggs-report-recall-election-looks-certain/35927159

https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/543803-california-recall-organizers-submit-21-million-signatures "Of the signatures submitted, just over 64 percent represent Republicans, about 25 percent are from people with no party preference and 9 percent are from Democrats" Another poll shows 38% in favor of the recall. It will be months and months away and I bet tempers will cool by the time it gets there, especially if a decent challenger does not emerge.

Looks like the signatures are in for the recall.  While he still has support, if this is a special election, only two groups of people will vote. Those who want him in, those who want him out.  Key to winning and losing is who shows up to vote. https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/03/16/newsom-california-recall-appears-to-have-enough-signatures-1368400
California has made several recalls of governors in the past, so there is a decent probability. Given the distraction of COVID, it is unlikely that he will be recalled, and there will be a recall.
3% up yes, not considering the consensus.
Is it possible Governor Newsom is a longtime federal undercover SA with the DEA?

https://fox5sandiego.com/news/california-news/recall-newsom-effort-surpasses-goal-of-2-million-signatures/ They hit 2 million signatures and there's still days to go. They can now have a rejection rate of 25% and still hit the target. The recall is a virtual certainty.
There is in state support for the election, but the requirements to hold a recall election are less than actually removing the governor. He will continue to serve his term.

They almost certainly have enough signatures (84% validity rate is very high but that's what they've been at historically in this recall, and the last one.) 1.95 x 0.84 = 1.638 They only need shy of 1.5 million, so they could have a validity rate of closer to 77% and still meet the requirement at this stage. It's virtually assured that the recall will happen. I still strongly doubt he will be recalled. https://nypost.com/2021/03/08/newsom-recall-is-almost-certainly-a-go-after-reaching-1-95m-signatures/

They got enough signatures. https://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/542042-leaders-of-newsom-recall-effort-say-they-have-enough-signatures
So reducing no to 0. And the rest is 95/5.  I think he is safe, there is no inside Democrat party threat.

Newsom's approval rating has dropped sharply. I'm increasing my odds that he will be recalled, but not by much. No more recent update on signatures. I'm still doubtful they'll get the number they need.

https://ballotpedia.org/Gavin_Newsom_recall,_Governor_of_California_(2019-2021) Signatures continue to increase.  Couple of polls on issue look fairly evenly split whether the recall or not.  Good list of people out to support newsom including Biden.  Cade of better the devil you know in a time of uncertainty like now.  Keeping prédiction same

They're now claiming 1.825m (https://recallgavin2020.com/) as of yesterday, with 13 days to go. If the 84% signature validity holds, they'll need 1,780,606 signatures in order to hit the 1,495,709 valid signatures which they've collected assuming they're telling the truth. Their goal is 2m with about 13 days left to go. That means they'd need to collect about 13,000 per day. Still unreasonably high, but also they're likely to hit the number of valid signatures. I'm adjusting my forecast to give the edge to the recallers.
After French Laundry to celebrate non-recall, he can drop by Pelosi’s for some gourmet ice cream!

California recall efforts are not terribly successful. Of the 178 attempts, only 6 have been successful, most being local positions, not statewide efforts. Only one statewide office (governor) was recalled in 2003. If there are even enough signatures to get the recall petition on the ballot, the odds it will pass are very slim as it's a minority of the minority party in the state calling for the recall election and thus does not have the popular support, barring a major scandal.
Yes but not up 10% to be ahead of the consensus. Left to my non-Bier thinking, probably more like 75%. FWIW

Not changing my forecast. However, the challenge will be all the signatures. Where oh where did they come from?  Recently a Lawyer in Solano county California told be judges don’t care about signatures. I wonder if that stimulated an IC3 complaint?
Chance Dems bump it outside the window or it is successful. But most likely they get their recall and it fails.

This vox article gives a good overview of the process [1]. It seems very likely that the recall campaign will be able to collect enough signatures to force an election. However, from the vox article it suggests it is unlikely the recall will be successful. Newsom has a decent approval rating in the 40s to 50s and California has become increasingly democratic over the past 20 years since the last recall. Based on current number of signatures, it is almost certain that the measure will be on the ballot, but governor's are hardly ever recalled. Gray Davis, the only other California governor to be recalled, had a worse record than Newsom. Also, despite pandemic frustrations, I believe it unlikely for Californians to recall a governor in the middle of a public health crisis.

An excellent article by the LA Times explains that there is likely enough signatures to force a recall election, but I am not convinced that CA voters would actually recall the Governor [1]. Updating my forecast slightly because I think it's even less likely that Newsom gets recalled now that I've read this: https://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2021/02/18/infighting-rattles-republican-party-bid-to-oust-gov-newsom/ "California Republicans eager to recall Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom could see their chances eroded by longstanding friction between the party’s conservative and moderate wings" Additionally, CA residents have tried to recall their Governor 55 times but have only been successful once: https://www.foxnews.com/politics/over-80-percent-of-submitted-newsom-recall-signatures-have-been-verified This Fox article also notes that they have 1.7 million signatures, but have only submitted 1.2m. ~80,000 in 26 days would be 3100, which is very doable. However, 1.7 x 0.84 = 1.428m which is below the 1.495. They want 2 million to ensure they're above the 1,495,709 valid. 300,000 / 25 days = 12,000 a day which is a lot harder. So this will come down to what target they need to hit and how accurate they're being in their own numbers.

Gubernatorial recall elections are rare. There have been only 2 successful in history. However, one of them was in California (2003), Gray Davis. They currently have about 60% of the needed signatures (around 900,000 valid ones), with around 84% of all signatures being found valid. 
 (https://www.politico.com/states/california/story/2021/02/19/newsom-recall-drive-faces-tight-finish-based-on-latest-california-data-9425479) They have 280 days to collect 1,495,709 valid signatures. (https://ballotpedia.org/Gavin_Newsom_recall,_Governor_of_California_(2019-2021) Assuming the 84% validity rate holds - which is approximately the same validity from the 2003 recall, they really need 1,780,606 signatures to finish with enough valid ones which implies collecting around 6,359 signatures per day, if it were linear, which we know it's not. After 255 days, at this rate they should have collected 1,621,545 signatures of which 1,362,097 are valid. Instead, they have collected around 1.1 million (~4313 per day) and validated 668,000. With 26 days remaining, to collect 680,606 signatures (to hit the 1.78m figure above) means they need to collect 26,177 per day which seems high relative to their previous activity. There could be a push to collect more signatures in the waning days. I was originally going to put the probability of "no recall" at 60%, but in the 2003 recall they needed to collect 897,158 signatures in 160 days and ended up collecting 1.6m, of which 1.3m were validated. So I downgraded the probability to 55%. If they do have a recall, he is unlikely to be recalled because because Governors are rarely recalled (38%), and 2% that if the recall vote occurs, that he gets recalled.

I look forward to being shown where I am wrong, but I took a closer look at the numbers and am moving the odds of the recall ballot signatures being met as highly probable. Seems to be about a three week delay in reported gross signatures received by Recall Newsom group until recorded as submitted by the various counties.  So the early March update should have about 1.5 million raw, 1.1 million verified, and low 900s validated. That will leave about two weeks for the recall people to get the rest of the signatures in. It’s just really hard to imagine with the ball rolling like it is that they won’t hit the goal. It will likely be sometime in April when enough signatures are validated. The recall election itself will be a strange ballot where first you say yes or no on recalling Newsom, and then you select from a menu of candidates after that. Here is what the ballot looked like in 2003: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c6/Sample_ballot_for_CA_recall.png  Gray Davis lost by about 10 points, with a significantly lower approval rating than Newsom has today. It is therefore likely he will win, but again it will depend on what his approval rating does between now and then, what the turnout is, and it will also depend on who his opponents are.

Initial forecast. Actually a low bar for an initiative in CA. While not "perfect" Newsom's record is probably better than Gray Davis'.

New numbers just in: https://elections.cdn.sos.ca.gov/recalls/cumulative-newsom-heatlie.pdf  As of Feb. 5, there were about 1.096 million signatures reported received by the CA Secretary of State's office. So far 83.7% of those that have been checked (798,000 as of that date) have been accepted as valid.  (The Recall Gavin 2020 group as of that date had reported 1.4 million received on their side.)  They look to be pretty much on pace, but there's going to be a severe backlog in getting the signatures verified. As far as I can tell, only 312,650 were even checked by the California county elections officials in the period from 1/6/21 to 2/5/21. This ups the risk of legal challenges and so on, so I'm bumping the No odds up to 10%, at least temporarily.

The petition has the required signatures but need some more for rhe inevitable disqualifications, so there is a chance it does not happen.  He does not seem to be challenged from his own party so he has his support.
So far, his ratings are decent, above 50%. I'll need to monitor this in case of freefall.

95% chance the recall happens, because they hit the 1.5 million threshold a few days ago, and their new goal in the final 30 days is another few hundred thousand, to account for a percentage of signatures being ruled invalid. Newsom still seems the favorite to win the recall election, although there could be some popular Democrats jumping in, which would induce some voters to put "yes" on the recall who otherwise wouldn't. It will also depend on the turnout and whether Newsom's approval rating goes up from here.
